ONE morning the old Water-rat put his head out of his hole. "Eeks!"
 cried the old Cruncher.
 "What's that?"
 "I can't understand a single word that that old wretch's talking about!"
 "Just as well!" replied the old Water-rat. "It isn't worth while paying any
 attention to him, unless he wants to know what the world is made of. I
suppose he's having a talk with the Cruncher."
 "Oh! Ee-ek!" said the old Cruncher, shaking from head to foot in
terror. "Bless my stick! Now the devil has come!"
 Then the rat asked, "Do you want to know what the world is made of?"

BEWARE THE RAT!

“And what, pray, is your idea of the duties of a devoted friend?” asked a Green Linnet, who was sitting in a willow-tree hard by, and had overheard the conversation.
“Yes, that is just what I want to know,” said the Duck; and she swam away to the end of the pond, and stood upon her head, in order to give her children a good example.
“What a silly question!” cried the Water-rat.  “I should expect my devoted friend to be devoted to me, of course.”
“And what would you do in return?” said the little bird, swinging upon a silver spray, and flapping his tiny wings.
“I don’t understand you,” answered the Water-rat.
“Let me tell you a story on the subject,” said the Linnet, who had a large green bough about twenty feet long, and six feet in diameter, which he used to make a nest upon against the side of the pond.  “Once upon a time there lived in a far country a little child and his mother and father.  The dear old father loved his children very dearly, but as an old uncle had told him that none of his family had ever lived to the age of seventy, and he himself only just reached the age of seventy-seven, he did not think it worth while to marry, and put them all in a great confusion.  The dear little children used to talk to him so about getting married in town that he got quite tired of it for a while, but the uncle, who lived in the same village, persuaded him to go to him, and there he got married. “‘Don’t you understand your own language?’ said the father, who did not know any.

Their names were: Peony, Jack, Jerry, Alice, Tommy, Daisy, Dolly, Peter, and Henry; and the children used to pretend that nothing was further from their minds than going into Mrs. Giant’s garden: but they would always go in and watch the Giant for half an hour.

The children had a great time in getting to know him. Every one used to say that he had a very dull face, for he only looked at his work and never spoke; and those who looked at him more carefully found that the ground upon which he walked felt soft underneath him, and that a hollow grew beneath him, but it always made a noise the longer he went on his way.

The children used to laugh at all these stories, and often hearken for his steps; and when they heard them coming, and knew them and feared them, they used to all go nearer together to watch what he was doing. After that the children used to go and sit by the Giant, and watch him work, and be taken to the farm, and do all sorts of odd jobs, but always he was always polite, and gave them cake and something sweet; and if any one was ill he would come and see him, and take the children home with him for his amusement. But the children always suspected a trick in everything he did.

The Giant and the pig went about the different parts of the farm, turning the wheels and throwing the peas through the threshing machine. The pease kept sticking together so that when they were carried away to the market every one laughed at them.

THE BUNDLE COMES BACK

“What are you doing here?” he cried in a very gruff voice, and the children ran away.
“My own garden is my own garden,” said the Giant; “any one can understand that.  I built it, and it is of such beauty that I love to look at it when I am out of doors; it makes the sun upon my face and the dew on my grass, and I love to come in and look at it at all hours.”
“Mine is an old house,” said the King, “built many centuries ago, and it needs the help of many people to keep it in order; it needs that they should have leisure to do it, and that they should not be disturbed from their work, but I should like you to take things in hand so that you may take charge of the garden.”
Immediately the Giant went to the King.  He took the children by the hand and began to lead them into the garden.  As he turned to go he said to the King: “O King! whatever I do, let me not forget my own garden.”
“You may take things in hand,” replied the King, “but if I ever hear you say anything disrespectful about the garden of the King you will be treated as a thief.”
“You say that with truth,” said the Giant, “but you must not forget that it is not alone you who has let me into your house to live among you—that you invited me to do so; but I would not have chosen to leave my own estate without my own consent.”  The King understood the Giant’s words well.  “I hope you will live happily here,” he said, “and as you came to my house you remain my guest in my house, and may stay as long as you choose.”

The Giant grew more and more happy, and his health became better as well.
For one whole year the children did not go to play in the Giant’s garden.
“We do not need to play in your garden,” he said.  “We may amuse ourselves in other ways; so I will stay here by myself all the time.”
It was a great comfort to him to come every day out of his house into the garden, to sit down by the entrance door, and to chat to himself until it was time to go back. And when the day came he made no effort to talk to anybody about the house which he had taken into his own, and which was no longer his.  That would have required a strength that he could not have had.  It was a very easy matter for him to accept the invitation of the King to live the hospitality of that house.  He was not going to pass on forever the beautiful summer afternoons in the garden.

By this diversion she made her lips and teeth so thin that she could not speak very well. At last, at the end of a week, the Giant let the little girl out and told her to go through the gate.
All went very quiet at the palace since the disappearance of the Princess, but no one had any doubt but that he would soon pay for her crime.  He had to wait three months, however, but his impatience at the stillness was greater than his cruelty.  Besides, he had to keep a strict look-out at his garden, and since nothing could be seen, he had no excuse for coming out to see it.
One day he came very late.  As he came out he saw the Princess crawling through the hedge.  He caught her at once and carried her into her closet. For five days he kept her in the closet without letting her see a single ray of sunshine, and her mouth was so thin that she could not speak a word.  She had not given up her attempts to break out, and she often crawled up the wall in order to make her voice heard above the continual din of the Peasants.  At last, however, she became too weak to crawl.  The Giant thought that when she was well enough she would tell a useful tale, and perhaps so it was that he brought her, one fine day, to the King.

yellow, the oats were green, the hay was stacked up in the green
meadows, and the stork paraded about on his long red legs, talking
in Egyptian, which language he had learnt from his mother.

The fields and meadows were skirted by thick woods, and a deep lake lay
in the midst of the woods. Yes; it was indeed beautiful in the country!
The sunshine fell warmly on an old mansion, surrounded by deep canals,
and from the walls down to the water's edge there grew large burdock
leaves, so high that children could stand upright among them without
being seen.

This place was as wild as the thickest part of the wood, and on that
account a Duck had chosen to make her nest there. She was sitting on
her eggs; but the pleasure she had felt at first was now almost gone,
because she had been there so long, and had so few visitors, for the
other Ducks preferred swimming on the canals to sitting among the
burdock leaves gossiping with her.

At last the eggs cracked one after another, "Chick, chick," they
cried; "do not forget your mother,"--and she wept; but she soon dried
her tears and said: "When I began to hatch out my chicks I was very
happy, but now that I am grown up I know that I can never fly;
but, still, it is good to feel that one is going to be born again."

All the other Chicks were on the same side of the water and were
showing their necks and legs at the water-side, but the Duck that had
been sitting on the eggs made her nest in the most inaccessible spot
in the forest.

She knew that some day the young ones would begin to swim about, and
her nest would be left in the middle of the forest with no one to
caring for it, if the Mother Duck returned no more; so she put sticks
in the nest to catch the wing-eggs,--but they missed them, and thought
it might have been the wind that had carried them away,--for the Duck
did not feed her family much, although she had laid so many eggs.

She just gave them eggs to drink, and, after they were hatched, she
would dash off so fast that nothing could catch her.

Now, this Duck was just like our Mother Earth, caring for her
family only when she was themselves grown up.

This last day seemed a very long one to the Chicks, for nothing but
lullabies had been heard since they were hatched; yet no one at meal
time was seen making his appearance.

At last some Chicks decided to go over to the water-side. Seeing that
their mother was near the nest they all splashed water over the edge
to cool themselves, as birds always do when they are going to be
born again; and, strange to tell, the Mother Duck, frightened at first
by this noise, took the Chicks and flew after them.--And when they had
swam a little way out of the forest they came to a deep pool, which
was just the one they were looking for to cool themselves before
hatching, having thought their mother would come to feed them.

The mother Duck led the way to the edge of the pool, and the young Chicks
ran after her, as fast as they could swim.

The moment they reached the edge of the pool the water poured over
the edges, and the Duck called to the Chicks: "Be quick or you will
slip;" and as she said this her feet dropped into the water and she
could hardly draw them out again.

All the Chicks dashed into the water, but the Duck did not wait long
before diving head first and swimming out far away before she
spoke to her young ones again.

She had been out more than half an hour, and now her breast began to
be covered with water.

She kept on swimming slowly, but every now and then she would stop
to rise on her bill two or three times.

It was not until the sun got near the mountains that she began to dive
again.

The Duck dived in this way nearly all day; but as the sun was shining
brightly through the leaves on this side of the forest, I was surprised
to hear of her success.

When she tried it again the next morning each and every one of her own
young Chicks was swimming the water like a fish.

Now it happened that the mother Duck went out to eat at an apple tree
and stood upon a stump and spoke to her young ones

cold.

showed him through the trees, as though she saw what he was looking

"We have a long year before us!" sighed all the Ducklings, "and many
times as we grow, we shall always be little Ducks!"

The old Duck thought they did not understand her; but suddenly the
large egg cracked, and out flew half a dozen small ones. There stood the
old Duck, rubbing her eyes. Then she understood them to the full. And
from this time on they grew rapidly in weight and size, for a large
quantity of food is needed for the development of each Duckling, and
it grows up in its turn, so that it becomes itself able to feed its
self.

THE TWELVE DUCKS

THE twelve Ducks lived happily together all their lives, except once
when the eldest among them fell ill and died. In place of the eldest
Duck, a new one was hatched. The others were almost afraid of it, but
he soon sat up and said, "How healthy I am! I will get up for a walk."

They all began to follow him about and to take care of him. But in
a few hours he had caught cold, and was laid in the deep-green grass
by the shores of the lake. There he lay for two days and nights,
and then he begged to be carried. They laid him down by the edge of
the water, and carried him to the large green trees, and placed him up
among the branches. Then they gathered thick leaves and grass around
him, for that is all the sick Duck wants; and the Mother Duck brought
a little stick for her little heir to gnaw on. When he would lie
still with his face full of leaves, the Mother Duck herself laid on
his back, so that he could not get too hot. In two days the weather
became warm, and in three days he became well enough to stand upright.

"Now," said the Mother Duck, "we will begin our journey again."

So the twelve Ducks took an early train of steps, and were soon at the
nearest water. There was a great many fish in the water: some were quite
bigger than the Ducks, but he could see no food; so he sat down and
started to nibble a bit of pebble.

It was beautiful in the country. It was summertime. The wheat was
yellow, the oats were green, the hay was stacked up in the green
meadows, and the stork paraded about on his long red legs, talking
in Egyptian, which language he had learnt from his mother.

The fields and meadows were skirted by thick woods, and a deep lake lay
in the midst of the woods. Yes; it was indeed beautiful in the country!
The sunshine fell warmly on an old mansion, surrounded by deep canals,
and from the walls down to the water's edge there grew large burdock
leaves, so high that children could stand upright among them without
being seen.

This place was as wild as the thickest part of the wood, and on that
account a Duck had chosen to make her nest there. She was sitting on
her eggs; but the pleasure she had felt at first was now almost gone,
because she had been there so long, and had so few visitors, for the
other Ducks preferred swimming on the canals to sitting among the
burdock leaves gossiping with her.

At last the eggs cracked one after another, "Chick, chick!" All the eggs
were alive, and one little head after another peered forth. "Quack,
quack!" said the Duck, and all got up as well as they could. They peeped
about from under the green leaves; and as green is good for the eyes,
their mother let them look as long as they pleased.

"How large the world is!" said the little ones, for they found their new
abode very different from their former narrow one in the egg-shells.

"Do you imagine this to be the whole of the world?" said the mother.
"It extends far beyond the other side of the garden in the pastor's
field; but I have never been there. Are you all here?" And then she got
up. "No, not all, for the largest egg is still here. How long will this
last? I am so weary of it!" And then she sat down again.

"Well, and how are you getting on?" asked an old Duck, who had come to
pay her a visit.

"This one egg keeps me so long," said the mother. "It will not break.
But you should have observed, that when you broke your egg, it no longer
held the little legs and wings that the egg-shell forms. But now we are

of sitting in the boughs; besides, she thought her eggs must be quite close
to the water's edge. Suddenly she heard a great clamour. It sounded
like angry words, but she could not tell them. The noise grew louder
and louder until it reached her ears.

When the Mother Duck heard the clamour she came out with her eyes on

Saying this, and looking round to receive the answer that he expected, he beheld the girl’s flushed countenance and burning cheeks, and a smile on her lips when she replied:

“Well, but YOU have one in YOUR NECKLACE.”

“Hearts are like roses,” said the young Student; “some of them of a crimson dye, some of pale scarlet, and some of a blushing red; but still there is plenty of rose in all.”

“A BLUSH, even in the morning, may fade,” said the Philosopher; “but an HEART does not depend on either natural colour, or the hour when it is inflamed with love and emotion; it may be brightened and roused by the influence of the most powerful and seditious passion, and the brightest of human qualities.”

“And is it hers?” inquired Edward, “for if it be not, it must be that of which my friend has told me.”

Mrs. Dix replied in a very low tone, that it was, indeed, her own.

“Then,” said Edward, “you must bring red roses for her every day, and every day she must come to dance with me.”

But Mrs. Dix was so angry that she could not agree. “If this is her husband,” said she, “he deserves to die of a broken heart, for I will not dance with any one. But if it is her lover do you think she will come? No, she will never come whilst he lives,—for if he dies, she will die too.”

“Sweet Flower, of that you may be sure,” replied the Student, “for you are the first of woman that ever lived, that has caused me to love you, and to think of you day and night.”

Then the Student threw his arm about his beautiful Sweet Flower, and taking her hand, led her, side by side, through the beautiful garden of the Villa.

They went through it, and though the ground was green and fresh, there was no flower on it, for there was no Rose in sight.

Then Sweet Flower blushed with her beautiful color—for she was more beautiful than any flower—and she said, “I am afraid that we should not be satisfied with a rose that we could just name after the name of an Indian chief, but you are mistaken, for if you would look well to your rose, you would find many other roses than those of your garden,”

Then the Student was glad of the advice, though he could not find in his own garden such beautiful roses as those which his dear Sweet Flower pointed out.

But after awhile he saw, or seemed to see, a beautiful rose, but when they came near this, it was not so beautiful looking as they had hoped, for it was a good deal like the blackest blackberry-bushes of the land.

“Do you know,” said the Student, “that there are those who take pleasure in these things?” and he took another blackberry, and ate the fruit of it.

Come in!” And she and the young Student came in; and the door shut, and it was still. They could only hear the wails of the poor ones that were bitter with sorrow and weariness and the sweet songs of the flowers and the singing of the birds. And she and the young Student went up and down the hall of the dead. Sometimes when she approached the world where the young Student danced at her bidding, she could not turn from it, though it was the garden-wall—a dreadful world in some ways—fain would she turn from it, and could only exclaim, “Come, sweet soul, come, come!” And he smiled and danced up and down before her, and she, holding him in her arms, stood quite still with the words flying through her mind, “Come, dear soul, come, come, come!” and he answered: “It is not for me to come, but for thee to come.” So she went on from one garden into another and he still danced before her, and they stood quite still. Came from the green, from the garden green

There never was a garden fairer,

Fain could I linger where I stood,

From her nest in the holm-oak tree the Nightingale heard him, and she looked out through the leaves, and wondered.
“No red rose in all my garden!” he cried, and his beautiful eyes filled with tears.  “Ah, on what little things does happiness depend!  I have read all that the wise men have written, and all the secrets of philosophy are mine, yet for want of a red rose is my life made wretched.”
“Here at last is a true lover,” said the Nightingale.  “Night after night have I sung of him, though I knew him not: night after night have I told his story to the stars, and now I see him.  His hair is dark as the hyacinth-blossom, and his lips are red as the rose of his desire; but passion has made his face like pale ivory, and sorrow has set her seal upon his brow.”
“The Prince gives a ball to-morrow night,” he cried; “here let me hide myself, and from time to time, when the moon hangs in her glory upon her throne, I will ascend to thee from the wood, and I will pour out my tale to thee.”
“I will lead him to the balcony and to the windows,” whispered the Nightingale; “I will cover his steps with music, and lead him to the spot where he shall think he hears only the singing of the birds.”
“By the sun, I will be a lover unto him!” said the Student; and after that every night that summer he brought a red rose to the Nightingale.
On the eve of the ball, the Lady of the Pool arrived dressed in velvet and gold.
“You will go with me to the Palace, it is my wont,” she said; “the King asks for a dance.”
The Student did not answer.

The sun played on the red sails which billowed overhead; far out across the waters they could see the green hills of the land beyond, the dim blue mountains, and a deep blue sea dappled with green waves.  The earth, the air, the whole wide world grew radiant, and Chameleon felt that every breath that he drew was full of poetry and of music.  The city whirled round him; flowers and fruit and fruit-trees flashed and glitters; all wore golden raiment, and the streets were strewn with bright flowers.
Just by the gates they found the Queen, leading out Beauty. The Nightingale rose and flitted to the top of a rosemary-bush, and here she sang for hours long, weaving her song now as if it were music, now as if it were a tale.
The last echo of the song died away in the wood far, far behind them.
The young Student leaned against the tree, thinking hard, and his countenance showed nothing of his secret thoughts.
In the summer evening the music of the air seemed to be sweeter and sharper than at any other time of the year, and in that night, as he lay awake, listening to the songs from the tree, this Student found himself recalling the many women spoken of in his books, and, looking outside the window, he saw the red moon shining in upon him through the night-shades.  He heard a distant noise, and from the garden rose the old blacksmith hammering with a will.
“How late it is,” he said, as he arose and joined his wife and children. “I’d almost lost hope!”
“Dear husband, I think that maybe--!” was the answer, but the young man had heard his children whispering as they put away their toys and lay down to sleep, and listened with them.
Then once, and once only, did the old blacksmith speak of the red rose.
“It was he who died of hunger on St. Valentine’s Day,” he said.
“But, father--!”  said the little girl.
“Go to bed, and do not say another word, my child,” he answered.
In the morning the schoolboy read the story of St. Valentine, and as he sat, open-mouthed, before the fireplace at home, his mother asked:
“And what, dear boy, did you see in the wood on St. Valentine’s Day?”
The boy, still seated on the hearthrug, looked up at her:
“In the wood there was the King of Elfland,” he said slowly.  “Ah, yes; I saw him!  He was riding a horse so lovely as a sunflower, and when she had set upon the highway a red rose.”
“Alas!” his mother said, “that will prove to be the red rose!”

“Here at last is a true lover,” she said; and a fluttering of her wings made the young Student rise from the grass, and follow her to the edge of the wood, where the white birches rustled in the wind; and he listened when she sang the words to which he longed to hear her voice.
“He, like an hourglass, will bring forth his treasure,” she said.  “Like a cloud in a clear sky, like a crystal spring, like the summer moon, she shall be seen, and the heart of her lovers.  He shall dance until the last moment—until the stars that are on high shall nod upon the walls of her apartments, and the bells that are on the towers of the palace ring out.
“Like the apple that is on the bough, the flower that can never be found, she shall be hidden to them, as if she had not been. Long nights have I sung of him, and have dwelt upon his face, yet I can hardly tell whether I have pictured him rightly or not.
“The colours of his hair are golden: they are like lightnings gleaming from the snowy peaks, and his cheek on winter nights is the only star.
His eyes are the stars, and they shine out through dark streets; and the music of his voice is the sigh of millions of lovers who can never be united.
He walks in the morning alone in an empty city, and sighs as he goes up the steps of his palace.
I have been in his garden, where the old trees and the old roses have grown, and I have read the fair words of love that are carved upon the tombstones above him. 
“Oh, my heart, would you were happy,” I cried at midnight, “and that he were there to see you, to look on you, and to hold you in his arms.—Ah! alas! alas! a flower with red in it would be good.  But I can not make one.  No, I cannot; I did make one—and the flowers are dead.”

HIGH above the city, on a tall column, stood the statue of the Happy Prince. He was tall and he was broad, and his clothes were always of a golden hue. For he loved gold, and it came, like rain, to water his fields: and the very birds brought him their fruit, and the flowers themselves loved him when he spoke to them. And the Happy Prince, though he was great and good, yet he was not a wise man: he was only kind and merry, though he knew that there was mischief in the world. When he wanted to pass a day in quiet meditation, he climbed up the column, and built himself a little house out of the woodpecker's teeth, which had fallen to the ground; and there, taking a seat on the topmost rung, he turned his face upward to look at the world, for the birds loved him still, and the flowers wanted to grow and be seen by him. All the people loved him, and the deer came and bowed to him when he passed them: and the little white cat, who had come with him from the palace, wished every day to climb up and make himself at home under his arm.
There was a great man who loved to study, and who had lived many ages before the Happy Prince, and he had many books that he read, and he knew many things, and was very wise; and yet he felt that it was not enough to know all wisdom, and all the wonderful things that were done in the world, for some one should be happy also, and all the world should have rest and peace. He therefore climbed up to the top of a dark hollow tree, and let his hand fall on the Happy Prince's golden head, for he loved him; and he called to him by name, and he cried, or sometimes he wept, or sometimes he laughed; but his answers were always sweet and soft, and the Happy Prince loved him still, and talked with him about all the events in the world. It was a cold winter evening that they were talking together, for the Happy Prince had gone up to the top of the dark hollow tree that day to hide away from winter; and he sat alone in the snow, making a little room for the Happy Prince in the hollow trunk.
But there was nothing that the Happy Prince cared about so much as the wonderful things in the world. He wished to know everything and to hear of everything; and so he and the great man talked on until late into the night. And when daylight awoke, the Happy Prince wanted to go home, for he had a little white cat to take care of; and he called to the great man, who was asleep in the tree, and said: "Please let me climb down with you, for I am so cold that I must go home early; and please let me sleep in your home, for your bookcase is so full of wonders that I shall never know all the facts." The great man then dressed himself and helped the Happy Prince down the tree; but they both had such deep colds that they could not move.
The next morning they fell in behind the Happy Prince as he went in a great procession to the court of a great king. As they came up the shining, snow-covered road, the king's servants saluted him with great solemnity, and they bowed down before him, a hundred thousand men and women in their great bright gowns. But the Happy Prince answered them by shouting and laughing and blowing his nose all in a hurry.
"Oh, king," said he, "what folly is this to bow down to that old, long-haired idiot? Is it only from politeness, or because I have been good-natured? I am not such an easy fool."
"The Lord Almighty," replied the king, "has given us all our strength, and it is sufficient for us to know that the Lord is among us."

HIGH above the city, on a tall column, stood the statue of the Happy Prince.

THE Happy Prince stood there on clear days. Beneath a silver canopy in the shade of a great tree, and among the top branches on their widest sweep, the Prince sat on a beautiful stool, his white cap turned to the hot sun. On the seat of his stool stood a basin of sweet water, and the blue cup hanging from his hand, and the large round mirror, which, held in his strong hand, reflected his handsome face.

He was very beautiful and very happy, and in the world beyond nothing could be more so.

The Happy Prince was so wonderful that all who saw him wondered much at him. He was the most beautiful girl in the city, and he knew it and was happy with it--it was not possible even to think of anything more beautiful. His was a strange face—an extraordinary face. Only his eyes, and the very middle of his face, had the appearance of being human. Between his hands were twisted chains, and the chains were very light, and the Happy Prince was the master of all he saw and did. In this place he had free rooms, without windows, and no need for windows. No one could reach him by any means of escape: the walls were a thousand feet in height, the roof was miles and miles in thickness. The Happy Prince could control all the people who came near him, with his wonderful power of mind; and no one could ever break his magic chain, for only himself could remove it. On the throne beneath his hands was a beautiful jewel; and wherever the Happy Prince went, and at whatever time, he wore the same wonderful crown with twelve golden stars on it, which his mother had sent to him when she found him. The Happy Prince's palace at the top of the mountain was a great glass house, and at the bottom was a garden, whose green leaves grew in the water of a river that flowed through the whole of it.

The Happy Prince's mother was happy with him; rich and beautiful she was, and nobody could make her unhappy. He was a noble prince; and all the wise men in the city feared him and loved him, and were bound to obey him, if he chose to speak to them or command them.

But all the rest cared very little about him and his power. No one could find out how the Happy Prince sat on his throne, and no one could watch him to find out who was walking beside him, so secret and invisible were his movements. Indeed, without his being visible to a single human being—and yet everybody knew that he was—you could never meet the Happy Prince or speak to him.

It had been like this for many years. Nothing ever happened to please the Happy Prince. He heard wonderful tales of some places far away in the country, through which came strange sunbeams, which produced extraordinary and wonderful things. But he had never left the city, and his heart was so heavy that he longed for happiness.

As the sun shone more clearly and the Happy Prince sat down on the throne and looked out into the blue world beyond the marble roof, with its glittering columns and its strange beauty—as he sat and looked, thinking of nothing at all, except how much he hated the sunbeams for having never gone near him—his mother stood by him and asked him if he would like to know who was at the foot of the great marble steps, and what was going on in his palace.

But he said to her sorrowfully, "I don't care one single bit. But I do hate the sunbeams."

"They are the children of the sun," said his mother. "Can't you stand them so long as you stay under glass?"

"I can never leave this roof," said he. "You forget that it is my palace, and you can't tear it down."

"It is not your palace," said she. "It belongs to the sun; and so if you really hate the sunbeams so much you may stay here as long as you please."

"But," said he, "if the sun is so powerful beyond the roof why don't they come inside, and strike the roof straight through to this marble palace which is as strong as a castle."

"How can they strike the roof?" asked his mother. "They have no arms."

"But the roof is weak, and could break in and kill people," said he.

The Happy Prince's mother grew very angry. "That is nonsense, of course," she said. "The sunbeams never hurt anybody, and never will hurt anybody, because they are better than we are. They come into all the world, but never to any human being."

"And why?" said he.

"Because they are happy children," said she.

“Come with me, come with me,” said the Town Councillor, leading her away, “and I will show you something better than a Happy Prince and a Good Woman, that I know a Good Man and a Good Woman.”

“But will I change at night?” said the Reed, who had no wish to remain a Reed all her life.
“Of course not, for then you would not be what you are now,” is the answer.  But the Swallow did not explain it; she only watched to see the beauty of her new-won love fade away at night. “I am very glad to go to Egypt,” she said the day after when she left the Shrub for good.  “I do not want to remain the same.  I will give the Swallow a visit before I go. THE King’s son was going to be married, so there were general rejoicings. But the king had a wife already, so the general rejoicing was quickly extinguished into melancholy.

I do not believe my ancestors ever left their castle on the hill, never saw any other castle on the hill, and never ceased to look at the castle on the hill.

I can’t remember whether the general sorrow was caused by the loss of their son, or by the loss of their son, their youngest son, and heir to the throne…but something had happened during the night, and by morning it was clearly that we would not see the prince again.

There was the funeral, just as if the prince had been born in years of youth. There was the burial, just as if the prince had been buried in the tomb of the ancient kings. The mourning was over. The first year was over as well, but the princess had not yet died, which was a significant source of sadness.

“I longed for you, too,” she said.  “Still I was afraid.”
“Very much so,” he answered.  “Will you now go and take lodging with me?  I have a great banquet in store for you.”

[Picture: St. George’s Window at Eton showing the Duke and Duchess]
She was standing within the Gate of the Castle, looking at it.  The Prince noticed how tall she was, and thought to himself, “She is very tall.”
Then he saw her face, and thought to himself, “It matches exactly the picture.”

“The new Queen is very fair,” said the King’s son to his wife; but she answered, “I can’t match even that beautiful picture. Your father’s work is the most beautiful thing we ever had in the world.”

“And yet he is not a man, or even a reindeer,” said the Princess.
“He is a reindeer who is my brother,” said the Prince, and then he looked and saw that the reindeer’s ears were all wet and dripping with tears.  At that sight the Prince was touched with pity, and he kissed the reindeer’s ears.

He put his arm round her waist, and the two went into the castle together and up to her room.

“That is right,” she said.  “No one but us two must see us.”

At last he went to the door of their rooms, and, leaning against it, he listened.

The cold air seemed to fan his face of its whiteness as he muttered, “You have done your best to get rid of him!  You have destroyed the happiness of my son!  Now he shall be his own!”
